awd_titl_txt: The Topology and Hodge Theory of Algebraic Maps
awd_abstract_narration:
The award supports research in the field of algebraic geometry, the discipline devoted to the study of polynomial or algebraic equations. Algebraic equations are both beautiful and ubiquitous, as they describe many natural phenomena, from the motion of planets to the shape of leaves and flowers, to the behavior of microscopic particles. The goal of this research project is to study the deeper properties of the solutions to more complicated algebraic equations (called algebraic maps). The investigator plans to continue long-term investigation of the topology, Hodge theory, and cycle theory of algebraic maps. The close connection between the two main threads of the research, namely the discovery of new and deep aspects of the general theory and the study of fundamental examples, are the motivating principle behind the work. It is anticipated that the results will be of use to mathematicians (in algebraic geometry, combinatorics, and representation theory) and to mathematical physicists (in string theory). 

The investigator will explore the fundamental aspects of the general theory as well as important examples through five projects: to determine the supports of Hitchin fibrations in the case of the general linear group; to compactify the moduli space of Higgs bundles on a curve for every reductive group; to initiate a theory of perverse truncation and specialization with application to the algebraic topology of Hitchin systems; to determine, via the Ngo support theorem, the Betti and Hodge numbers of the only known remaining irreducible symplectic manifold for which these are not known; to establish and explain certain remarkable hidden symmetries on the cohomology of the moduli spaces of Higgs bundles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The award supports research in the field of algebraic geometry, the discipline devoted to the study of polynomial or algebraic equations. Algebraic equations are both beautiful and ubiquitous, as they describe many natural phenomena, from the motion of planets to the shape of leaves and flowers, to the behavior of microscopic particles. The goal of this research project is to study the deeper properties of the solutions to more complicated algebraic equations (called algebraic maps). The investigator plans to continue long-term investigation of the topology, Hodge theory, and cycle theory of algebraic maps. The close connection between the two main threads of the research, namely the discovery of new and deep aspects of the general theory and the study of fundamental examples, are the motivating principle behind the work. It is anticipated that the results will be of use to mathematicians (in algebraic geometry, combinatorics, and representation theory) and to mathematical physicists (in string theory).

 The investigator's work has been centered around the topology, Hodge and cycle theory of algebraic varieties and maps. For the duration of this grant, the investigator has explored the fundamental aspects of the general theory as well as important examples through five projects and his work has: 

1) determined the supports of Hitchin fibrations;

2) compactified the moduli space of Higgs bundles for every reductive group;

3) initiated a theory of truncation and specialization with application to Hitchin systems;

4) determined the Betti and Hodge numbers of the only known remaining irreducible symplectic manifold for which these are not known;

5) established and explain remarkable hidden symmetries on the cohomology of Hitchin systems.

 

All these projects have generated positive outcomes in terms of intellectual merit and of broader impacts.

 

 Intellectual Merit.

1), 2) and 5): deal with the Hitchin morphism, an object at the overlap of algebraic geometry, representation theory and mathematical physics. In 1), Heinloth , Migliorini  and the investigator pioneered the study of the morphism away from integral spectral curves. The investigator achieved in 2) a completion of the  Hitchin fibration. In 5),  Maulik,  Shen and the investigator have established the P=W Conjecture in the Non Abelian Hofdge Theory of a curve  in the case of genus two and prime rank for the special linear group. In 3), the investigator has started a detailed study of the existence of the specialization morphism for the perverse Leray filtrations of a family of morphisms. In 4), with  Rapagnetta and Sacca, he determined the Betti numbers of the manifold O'Grady 10,  the only known example of irreducible symplectic manifold with unknown Betti numbers. 

 

 Broader Impacts.

The investigator's funded research has been carried out also with experts in the U.S. and abroad. Together with the other scholarly activities of the investigator, it has played a role in: the education of post-docs, undergraduate and graduate students, via mentoring, advising and scientific collaboration; curriculum-design and course-creation; running/lecturing seminars, lecture series and geometry schools; running programs at his and others institutions; the publishing of lecture notes, books, and survey articles intended to reach the general mathematical public. The PI co-organizes the Stony Brook Algebraic Geometry Seminar (since 1999) and the Student Algebraic Geometry Seminar (since 2011). The PI's work has been the focus of a Bourbaki Seminar by G. Williamson (2016) and of lecture series and summer schools by other research groups in Strasbourg (2005), Freiburg (2010), Essen-Paderborn-Dusseldorf (2011), Warwick and Pisa (2015), Taithou (2018). The PI has taught several international winter and summer schools: Trento, Seoul, Trieste, Mexico City, Ann Arbor, Guanajuato, Cuernavaca, Park City. The PI has co-organized a Summer school for postdocs and graduate students at the Simons Center for Geometry and Physics at Stony Brook.

 

Summary of outcomes. 

As a result of the research funded by the grant, the investigator has published eight papers:

 Cohomology of the moduli of Higgs bundles via positive characteristic, (with D. Maulik, J. Shen, S. Zhang); to appear in Jour.Europ.Math.Soc., arXiv:2105.03043.

 On the P=W conjecture for SLn, (with D. Maulik and J. Shen); Selecta Math. (N.S.) 28 (2022), no. 5, Paper No. 90.

 Projective Completion of Moduli of t-Connections on Curves in Positive and Mixed Characteristic, (with S. Zhang); Adv. Math. 401 (2022) Paper No. 108329, 43pp

 Perverse Leray Filtration and Specialization with Applications to the Hitchin Morphism, Math.Proc. Cambridge Philos.Soc. 172 (2022), no. 2, 443-487.

 The Hodge numbers of O'Grady 10 via Ngo strings, (with A. Rapagnetta and G. Sacca`) J. Math. Pures Appl. (9) 156 (2021), 125-178.

 A support theorem for the Hitchin fibration: the case of GLn and KC, (with J. Heinloth and L. Migliorini) J. Reine Angew. Math. 780 (2021), 41-77.

 Compactification of Dolbeault moduli spaces, Int. Math. Res. Not. IMRN 2021, no. 5, 3543-3570.

The perverse filtration for the Hitchin fibration is locally constant,  (with D. Maulik) Pure Appl. Math. Q. 16 (2020), no. 5, 1441-1464.
